LOAN AND PROJECT SUMMARY 
 
Borrower  Republic of Indonesia 
   
Classification  Targeting classification: Targeted intervention 
Sector: Multisector 
Subsectors: Roads and highways, irrigation and drainage, water

Project Description  The Project will form part of the rural infrastructure component of 
the Government’s ongoing Fuel Subsidy Reduction Compensation 
Program (PKPS-BBM), and it will rehabilitate and improve rural 
infrastructure in about 1,800 poor and/or isolated villages in less 
developed districts in East Java, Nusa Tenggara East, South East 
Sulawesi, and South Sulawesi provinces. The Project will follow a 
community-driven development approach and will benefit about 2 
million people or about 400,000 households. 
   
Rationale  The Government’s National Poverty Reduction Strategy identifies 
lack of basic infrastructure in the rural areas as an underlying 
cause of poverty, and the Medium Term Development Plan 2004–
2009 (MTDP) identifies investing into rural infrastructure as a key 
action  for  reducing  poverty.  The  MTDP  identifies  investment 
needs of about $145 billion in infrastructure necessary to maintain 
a  sustained  GDP  growth  rate  of  6%  and  for  making  steady 
progress  towards  the  Millennium  Development  Goals  (MDG) 
during the planned period. Of these, public sector requirements 
are estimated at about $25 billion for infrastructure, such as that 
for  rural  areas,  that  is  traditionally  unattractive  for  the  private 
sector. However, investments in infrastructure have seen drastic 
decline from about $16 billion in 1996 to $3 billion in 2001 and to 
$1.5 billion in 2002. 
 
The urgency of investments in rural infrastructure has further risen 
with the Government’s ambitious plan to reduce fuel subsidies. 
The direct impact on the poor and near poor of, for example, a 
recent 186% rise in the price of kerosene is potentially substantial. 
Impacts resulting from higher transportation and energy costs will 
raise the general inflation levels. The direct and indirect impacts 
could further aggravate poverty levels and may lead to slippages 
in progress towards attaining MDGs. To mitigate these impacts 
and aid the poor and near poor, the Government has adopted a 
number of measures, including the rural infrastructure component

ii   
of  the  PKPS-BBM,  to  provide  basic  infrastructure  to  rural 
communities. On account of resource constraints, the coverage of 
the PKPS-BBM in 2005 is limited to about 12,800 (about 20%) of 
the villages in Indonesia, which leaves a large unserved rural 
population. In 2006, the PKPS-BBM targets an additional 9,000 
villages. The Project will support expansion of the Government 
program in an additional 1,800 villages with high incidences of 
poverty and poor rural infrastructure. That will raise the overall 
Program coverage to 23,600 villages. 
   
Impact and Outcome  The Project’s long-term objective is to improve welfare of the rural 
communities, and the immediate objective is to improve access of 
the poor and near poor in rural areas to basic rural infrastructure. 
   
Cost Estimates  The Project will be implemented as a part of the PKPS-BBM, 
which is estimated to cost about $698 million (inclusive of the 
Project costs and beneficiary contributions). The total costs of the 
geographic  slice  supported  by  the  Project  are  $60.82  million 
equivalent, of which $10.66 million (18%) is the foreign exchange 
cost and $50.16 million equivalent (82%) is the local currency 
cost.

Implementation  The Project will be implemented over a period of 30 months as 
Arrangements  part of the Rural Infrastructure Component in the Government’s 
ongoing  PKPS-BBM.  It  will  use  the  existing  implementation 
mechanisms  that  are  in  place  for  that  program.  The  project 
coordination  and  monitoring  unit  at  the  national  level  will  be 
responsible for the management, coordination, and monitoring of 
project activities. The existing provincial- and district-level project 
implementation units will be responsible for providing social and 
technical  facilitation  to  the  communities  in  undertaking  the 
infrastructure  rehabilitation  and  improvement  activities.  The 
National  Coordination  Team  and  the  National  Steering 
Committee, established for the PKPS-BBM, will be responsible for 
providing guidance and oversight to the Project. 
   
Executing Agency  The Ministry of Public Works through its Directorate General of 
Human Settlements will be the Executing Agency for the Project. 
   
Procurement  All goods and related services financed under the ADB loan will 
be  procured  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Guidelines  for 
Procurement under Asian Development Bank Loans. 
   
Consulting Services  An  estimated  702  person-months  of  consulting  services, 
comprising  8  person-months  of  international  and  694  person-
months of domestic consultants, will be recruited to assist the 
Government in implementing the Project. Eight person-months of 
international, and 16 person-months of domestic consulting, along 
with  an  appropriate  number  of  technical  support  staff,  will  be 
recruited on individual bases, while the remaining services will be 
procured through a domestic consulting firm. Consultants will be 
recruited  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of 
Consultants, using the quality and cost-based system and other 
arrangements  satisfactory  to  ADB  for  engaging  domestic 
consultants. 
   
Project Benefits and  The Project will benefit about 2 million rural poor in about 1,800 
Beneficiaries  poor  and/or  isolated  villages.  The  likely  types  of  infrastructure 
include  village  roads,  bridges  and  culverts,  village  irrigation 
schemes,  water  supply  and  sanitation  schemes,  and  drainage 
works.  Main  benefits  are  anticipated  to  include  (i)  reduced 
transportation costs, (ii) improved access to safe drinking water, 
(iii)  improved  access  to  sanitation  facilities,  (iv)  improved  crop 
production,  and  (v)  short-term  and  long-term  employment 
generation. The  experience  from  recent  projects  indicates  that 
such investments are economically viable, with economic internal 
rates of returns from the rural roads, irrigation schemes, and water 
supply schemes ranging from 28% to 85%.

iv   
Risks and Assumptions  The main risks the Project is likely to face include (i) possibly 
inadequate preparatory activities on the part of the Government, 
(ii) possibly inadequate implementation capacities at local levels, 
(iii) benefits accruing to a few nonpoor, (iv) poor governance, (v) 
sustainability of the policies and investments, (vi) start-up delays, 
(vii)  delays  in  budget  approval,  and  (viii)  lack  of  adequate 
counterpart funds. The Project design provides for measures that 
should be able to mitigate or minimize the perceived risks.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to the Republic of Indonesia for the Rural Infrastructure Support Project. 
 
II.  RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 
A.  Performance Indicators and Analysis 
2.  The rural areas in Indonesia are home to the largest segment of the population and of 
the poor. Based on official estimates,1 the number of rural poor in 2004 was about 24.7 million, 
or one fifth of the rural population. That represents a reduction of about 7.6 million (about 7 
percentage points) from the levels immediately following the 1997–98 Asian financial crisis. The 
poverty levels underestimate poverty, however, by not taking into account seasonal or transient 
poverty. An assessment of rural poverty,2 using the difference in incidence between $1/day and 
$2/day headcounts as a proxy for vulnerability, reports that as much as 45% of the overall 
Indonesian population may be vulnerable to periodic shocks. Although separate estimates on 
the size of the vulnerable population in rural areas are not available, the extent of vulnerability is 
expected to be at least similar if not higher for the rural population. The vulnerable in Indonesia 
live with risk as a part of their lives, and shocks at the national or regional levels can sink them 
into poverty at any time.  
  
3.  The  Government’s  poverty  reduction  strategy  paper  (PRSP) 3 and  Medium  Term 
Development Plan for 2004–20094 (MTDP) identify lack of key infrastructure as one of the 
underlying causes of poverty. Poor or difficult access to villages mean that the communities do 
not receive fair prices for their produce and they pay higher prices for their consumption. Poor 
access also means a tendency for poor coverage of public and private services and higher 
costs of accessing outside services. According to the MTDP, about 54% of the rural villages are 
not connected through asphalt roads, and about one third of these lack year-round access even 
by four wheel drive vehicles. A quick assessment undertaken by the country poverty analysis 
showed  that  in  isolated  areas  dependent  on  non-motor  vehicle  modes  of  transportation, 
communities identified high transportation costs as a major cause of poverty. According to the 
National Socio-Economic Survey,5 more than  40% of Indonesian households did not have 
access to clean drinking water or sanitation facilities in 2003. Among rural households, only 
15% were obtaining drinking water from piped or pumped sources, and just 21% had septic 
tanks for final disposal of human waste. The impacts of low levels of access to safe drinking 
water and lack of adequate sanitation facilities contribute to high incidence of such water-borne 
diseases as diarrhea, intestinal worms, and skin diseases. The incidence is higher among 
children and the elderly, and diarrhea is the second-largest cause of death and stunted growth 
among young children. The infant mortality rate of 35 per 1,000 live births in 2000 is the highest 
among Southeast Asian countries.

B.  Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 
1.  Adequacy and Sustainability of Rural Infrastructure 
4.  Historically,  Indonesia  has  had  high  levels  of  public  and  private  investments  into 
infrastructure. However, the investment levels have dropped sharply since the 1997–98 Asian 
financial crisis. In current terms, such public expenditures declined from about $16 billion in 
1996  to  $3  billion  in  2001  and  to  $1.5  billion  in  2002.  Declining  investments  mean  that 
infrastructure  expansion  has  slowed  and  existing  infrastructure  has  deteriorated.  A  recent 
assessment6 has ranked Indonesia at the bottom in terms of infrastructure amongst countries 
with  populations  of  more  than  20  million.  According  to  the  village  potentials  survey,7 the 
proportion of rural villages with year-round access by four wheel drive vehicles improved only by 
about 2 percentage points between 1993 and 2003 from 80% to 82%. Over the same period, 
the proportion of villages accessible by asphalt roads declined by about 2 percentage points to 
45% in 2003. Between 1993 and 2003, improvements in access to safe drinking water and 
sanitation in rural areas were relatively larger, at 6% and 22%, respectively. However, the 
overall coverage remains low. 
 
5.  Low levels of investment have also had adverse affects on the sustainability of existing 
infrastructure and service delivery levels. According to the MTDP, the condition of 46% of the 
overall road network and 57% of the district roads is categorized as lightly to heavily damaged. 
Similarly,  the  irrigation  schemes,  representing  an  important  infrastructure  element  in  the 
predominantly agriculture-based economy, are in a poor state. Up to 30% of the schemes are 
categorized as degraded. Appendix 1 presents a more detailed analysis of the sector-related 
issues and experiences. 
 
2.  Opportunities 
6.  The PRSP and Agriculture and Rural Development Strategy8 identify investing into rural 
infrastructure as a key area in reducing poverty and regional disparities, as well as for achieving 
the  Millennium  Development  Goals  (MDGs),  as  these  investments  improve  poor  people’s 
access to services and markets while generating employment. A recent Asian Development 
Bank (ADB) study9 confirmed that, in addition to the income-related impacts, investments into 
infrastructure also generate such non-income impacts as improvements in health, education, 
security, and participation. Taking into account the potential role of infrastructure development in 
reducing poverty, the MTDP emphasizes the need for increased investments into infrastructure 
in general and into rural infrastructure in particular. According to Government estimates, in order 
for  Indonesia  to  maintain  an  annual  GDP  growth  rate  of  6%  over  the  period  2005–2009, 
infrastructure investments of $145 billion are needed. Of that amount, $25 billion in public sector 
investments have been identified specifically in such areas as rural roads, irrigation, and other 
rural infrastructure that are typically not attractive for the private sector. 
 
3.  The Government Strategy and Program

offers justice and democracy to all its citizens, and (iii) is prosperous. This vision is the basis for

the MTDP, which emphasizes policy and institutional reform, an enhanced role and involvement 
of civil society, and active involvement of the private sector in providing infrastructure. The 
MTDP identifies five priority areas for achieving its GDP growth target of 6-7% per year. These 
are (i) supporting job creation and poverty reduction programs; (ii) maintaining macroeconomic 
stability through stable prices, fiscal sustainability, and financial sector reforms; (iii) accelerating 
growth of investments, exports, and tourism through reforms to create a healthy business 
climate  and  flexible  markets;  (iv)  improving  human  resources;  and  (v)  developing  the 
infrastructure. 
 
8.  In line with its vision and strategy of policy and institutional reforms, the Government has 
adopted a policy of reorienting public sector expenditures from general consumptive subsidies 
to targeted interventions aimed at the poor. The process has been hastened by the rising oil 
prices in the world markets, which led to substantial increase in fuel subsidies.10 Through a 
four-stage process, the Government has increased prices of fuel over a period of 8 months. As 
of 1 October 2005, the price increases for kerosene, gasoline, and automotive diesel relative to 
the 28 February 2005 levels amounted to 186%, 149%, and 161%, respectively. The price rise 
for kerosene, the common fuel for the poor, is anticipated to directly impact the consumption 
patterns of the poor. The poor will also be impacted by increased prices of gasoline and 
automotive diesel, as these will lead in turn to higher transportation costs and inflation.  
 
9.  When  faced  with  income-related  shocks,  the  poor  tend  to  liquidate  assets,  borrow 
excessively,  and  cut  expenditures,  especially  for  nutrition,  health,  and  education.  This 
aggravates poverty. The increased kerosene prices may also lead to adverse effects on the 
environment, as the rural population may increase its dependence on wood as a fuel. Unless 
effective mitigation measures are implemented, the removal of subsidies may cause slippage in 
progress toward achieving the major MDGs—including those relating to eradicating poverty and 
hunger, providing safe water, and environmental sustainability. To compensate for the reduced 
fuel subsidies, the Government has initiated a series of targeted interventions to establish and 
improve  safety  nets,  as  well  as  to  increase  investments  into  health,  education,  and  rural 
infrastructure.  Some  of  these  are  components  of  the  so-called  Fuel  Subsidy  Reduction 
Compensation Program (PKPS-BBM). The Government has put in place the following main 
interventions: 
(i)  Unconditional cash transfer. Cash transfers to an estimated 15.5 million poor 
and near-poor households. Allocation of Rp4.7 trillion ($470 million equivalent) in 
the 2005 budget. 
(ii)  PKPS-BBM–Education  Component.  Operational  aid  to  schools  with  an 
allocation of Rp6.3 trillion ($630 million equivalent) in the 2005 budget. 
(iii)  PKPS-BBM–Health Component. Basic health care and health insurance for the 
poor with an allocation of Rp3.9 trillion ($390 million equivalent) in the 2005 
budget. 
(iv)  PKPS-BBM–Rural  Infrastructure  Component.  Allocations  of  $330  million 
equivalent in the 2005 budget and a further $250 million equivalent in the 2006 
budget. 
 
10.  PKPS-BBM – Rural Infrastructure Component. The rural infrastructure component, 
formulated by the regional development directorate of the National Planning and Development 
Agency (BAPPENAS), the Ministry of Public Works (MPW), and the State Ministry of Less

Developed Regions builds upon some of the recent rural development projects that take a 
community-driven  development  approach.  The  approach,  closely  following  infrastructure 
development components of phases I, II and III of the Kecamatan Development Project (KDP) 
and ADB’s Community and Local Government Support Program, provides block grants to the 
communities for meeting their priority infrastructure needs. Each village is entitled to a block 
grant of about $25,000 for meeting its priority infrastructure needs, which may include village 
roads, village irrigation schemes, water supply and sanitation, and small fish landing facilities.11 
A more detailed account of the PKPS-BBM is presented in Appendix 2. 
 
11.  PKPS-BBM is intended to cover some 28,000 infrastructure projects in poor villages. 
The 2005 activities, with a budgetary allocation of about $330 million, aim to provide basic 
infrastructure to some 12,800 villages in 427 of 459 districts.12 Overall, the 2005 activities take 
in about 20% of villages in the country and about 45% of the infrastructure-poor villages. In 
eastern islands, where the majority of the districts are classified as less developed, proportions 
of villages not covered by the Program are high. Plans call for 2006 activities to cover another 
9,000 villages at a cost of about $250 million from the Government’s own resources. The 
estimated  costs  of  the  PKPS-BBM  for  2005  and  2006,  inclusive  of  voluntary  community 
contributions, is estimated at about $638 million, which is anticipated to be supplemented by 
additional coverage through external assistance.  
 
4.  Past Rural Infrastructure Initiatives and Lessons Learned 
12.  Indonesia has extensive experience in implementing both dedicated rural infrastructure 
projects and broader rural development projects with infrastructure-related focus. The external 
assistance for rural infrastructure aggregates to about $14.6 billion. Of that, the respective 
shares  of  rural  development  projects  with  infrastructure  components,  water  supply  and 
sanitation, roads, and irrigation are $2.28 billion, $0.60 billion, $4.95 billion, and $4.77 billion 
(Appendix 3). The community-driven development approach has been tried and tested on both 
locally  and  externally  funded  projects,  and  it  has  proven  successful.  Some  of  the  major 
initiatives along the lines of community-driven development include the Village Improvement 
Project (1994–96), KDP phases I, II and III (1998 to date), Community and Local Government 
Support Program (1999–05), Poor Farmers’ Income Improvement through Innovation Project 
(2001–to date), and PKPS-BBM Rural Infrastructure Component (2005 to date).  
 
13.  Despite a large number of ongoing and recently completed projects, only a part of the 
basic infrastructure needs of the rural population has been met. In aggregate, recent projects 
and programs have covered about 50% of the 68,000 rural villages in the country, which leaves 
a large number of rural villages with unmet rural infrastructure needs. Furthermore, due to 
resource constraints, not all basic infrastructure needs will have been met even in those rural 
villages that have been covered in the past. 
 
14.  Following are the key lessons that have been learned from implementing these recent 
projects and programs:

(i)  Pro-poor geographic targeting of project activities increases the poverty impact of 
rural development. 
(ii)  Community facilitation in community planning and preparation is a key factor for 
success  of  projects.  Facilitator  recruitment,  training,  supervision,  and 
replacement should be undertaken in a timely and synchronized manner. 
(iii)  The communities should be provided close technical backstopping to help ensure 
that the design of the civil works is appropriate, quality of civil works is high, and 
any adverse impacts on the environment are readily mitigated. 
(iv)  Communities should be thoroughly briefed on administrative- and procurement-
related procedures, so that they can monitor implementation progress. Such 
accountability procedures as public disclosure of budgets, tenders, contracts, 
and terms of reference ensure good governance and help prevent fraud and 
corruption.  
(v)  Implementation arrangements should include measures to ensure that minority 
groups within the community participate and benefit from the Project activities. 
(vi)  Simple fund flow arrangements with direct transfer to the community accounts 
reduce the chances of leakages. 
(vii)  Communities should be trained and facilitated in establishing effective operating 
and maintenance mechanisms. 
 
15.  The PKPS-BBM is in its first year of implementation. A full assessment of development 
effectiveness and adequacy of design and financial systems is due at the completion of 2005 
activities. As a part of the Project processing, initial implementation of the PKPS-BBM was 
thoroughly assessed through discussions with key stakeholders, field visits, and examination of 
relevant  records  and  guidelines.  The  PKPS-BBM  was  found  to  be  well  designed,  ably 
administered, and with sound financial management systems and fiduciary controls. In addition, 
the assessment highlighted the following lessons based on the initial implementation: 
 
(i)  Simplified implementation mechanisms and minimal involvement of government 
agencies at various administrative levels have been more successful. 
(ii)  A fixed grant size may not be appropriate for all villages, as average village sizes 
and availability of existing infrastructure greatly differ between provinces and 
districts. 
(iii)  Grant size should be based on simple, objective, and transparent criteria so that 
the community members are aware of the grant amounts to which they are 
entitled. 
(iv)  A longer implementation period with geographic phasing of activities within the 
districts will help provide sufficient preparatory activities and avoid bunching of 
approvals for village infrastructure plans. 
(v)  A longer implementation period provides opportunities for periodic stocktakings 
and improving the Project design. 
(vi)  Simple and objective selection criteria can help improve transparency in village 
selection and improve poverty targeting. 
(vii)  Selection criteria for infrastructure should take into account financial and cost 
effectiveness considerations in addition to technical aspects. 
(viii)  In addition to the input and output monitoring, the Project should also monitor 
process, impact and outcome. 
(ix)  Project monitoring and evaluation should be provided dedicated resources to 
help avoid diverting resources and emphasis during peak implementation periods.

5.  ADB’s Sector Objectives and Strategy 
16.  The Indonesia country strategy and program update13 provides strategic support for the 
Government in critical areas, including (i) continuing support for implementing the Government’s 
decentralization policies, (ii) supporting social development, (iii) promoting long-term economic 
growth through infrastructure operations and private sector participation, and (iv) furthering 
regional cooperation through investments in the transport and energy sectors. The proposed 
Project is consistent with the strategy, as it aims to support social development and promote 
long-term  development  in  rural  areas  through  infrastructure  improvement.  In  its  forward 
planning,14 ADB envisages a two-pronged strategy of pursuing a greater private sector role in 
the larger infrastructure and an increased public sector role in developing rural infrastructure. 
The forward plans envisage rural infrastructure development as a key factor in reducing poverty, 
improving MDG attainment in MDG-deficit geographic areas, strengthening rural-urban linkages, 
and developing rural economies. 
 
III.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
17.  The Government has requested ADB to assist in improving rural infrastructure as a part 
of its ongoing initiatives under the PKPS-BBM to mitigate the adverse impacts on the poor and 
near poor of reduced fuel subsidies. The Project’s long-term objective is to improve the welfare 
of  rural  communities,  and  the  immediate  objective  is  to  improve  access  to  basic  rural 
infrastructure for the poor and near poor in rural areas. The Project’s design and monitoring 
framework is Appendix 4.  
 
18.  The Project will implement a geographic slice of the 2006–2007 PKPS-BBM where it will 
cover selected provinces in eastern Indonesia with poverty levels higher and achievement levels 
on the Millennium Development Goals lower than national averages. The selection of provinces 
also took into account the number of less developed districts and presence of infrastructure-
poor villages. The selected provinces are East Java, Nusa Tenggara East, South East Sulawesi, 
and  South  Sulawesi.  The  poverty  profiles  of  the  selected  provinces  are  presented  in 
Supplementary Appendix A. Within these provinces, the Project will focus on less developed 
districts15 with high poverty levels, sufficient implementation capacities, and adequate numbers 
of villages that are eligible for support. Within the selected districts, only those villages will be 
eligible for support that have (i) poverty levels higher than the district average, (ii) lower density 
of infrastructure than the district average, and (iii) not received support in the past 2 years for 
infrastructure development. Inclusion of the more specific criteria adds objectivity to the village 
selection, and the use of additional filters helps target remote and isolated villages that have 
been bypassed by previous projects/programs. The list of selected districts and villages will be 
finalized and submitted to the ADB prior to commencement of civil works and release of funds in 
each of the Project districts.

B.  Outputs 
19.  The Project will comprise two components, namely (i) infrastructure rehabilitation and 
improvement; and (ii) implementation, monitoring and coordination support. 
 
1.  Part A: Infrastructure Rehabilitation and Improvement 
20.  This component will target the poor and/or isolated villages that have not received recent 
assistance in rehabilitating and improving infrastructure. Following the PKPS-BBM approach,16 
the component will provide villages with social and technical facilitation and financial resources 
to meet their priority infrastructure needs. Likely infrastructure projects may include village roads, 
bridges and culverts, village irrigation schemes, water supply and sanitation, and drainage 
works. Selection of the infrastructure will be subject to technical feasibility, cost effectiveness, 
financial  feasibility,  and  screening  for  social  and  environmental  safeguards.  Each  of  the 
participating villages will be eligible for a grant of up to $25,000 equivalent for rehabilitating and 
improving priority infrastructure needs. In cases of larger or very less developed villages, the 
Project  will  adopt  a  more  flexible  approach  by  providing  additional  grants  at  successful 
implementation of a first grant, which will allow for improving the depth of support. In cases of 
villages in Alor district of Nusa Tenggara East that were affected by the November 2004 
earthquake, the villages will also be entitled to further grants at successful completion of initial 
infrastructure plans. During implementation, the findings of monitoring, evaluation, and special 
studies will be used to assess the appropriateness of the grant size. If needed, then, the Project 
will develop a simple, transparent, and objective mechanism for introducing flexible sizing of 
grants that is linked to per capita infrastructure availability. 
 
21.  The component will follow a three-stage approach, wherein the first stage will include an 
awareness  campaign,  community  mobilization,  and  capacity  building  for  the  communities. 
During this stage, a given village community will form a community implementation organization 
(CIO), which will elect a representative committee comprising five members to represent their 
interests. The members will include at least one female and one member from a minority group, 
if any are present in the village.  
 
22.  In  the  second  stage,  the  community  will  be  facilitated  by  district-level  public  works 
services, with the help of village organizers, to assist in planning and designing the priority 
infrastructures.  The  design  of  community-selected  infrastructure  rehabilitation  and 
improvements will be based on detailed guidelines prepared for the PKPS-BBM and amended 
to incorporate ADB policies on procurement and safeguards. Upon approval of an infrastructure 
rehabilitation and improvement plan (IRIP), 40% of the grant will be transferred by the district 
treasury  office  directly  into  the  community’s  bank  account  as  an  advance  payment.  The 
remaining funds, subject to certification of progress by the district and subdistrict public works 
services staff, will be disbursed to the community in two installments, of 40% and 20%, which 
will be disbursed at the 36% completion point and the 72% completion point, respectively. 
 
23.  In the third stage, the communities will be facilitated in developing and establishing 
operating and maintenance mechanisms. In the process, the CIO will either reconfirm the 
existing representative committee or will establish a new committee tasked with operating and

C.  Special Features 
1.  Support for Government’s Ongoing Program 
26.  The Project will support and enhance implementation of the ongoing PKPS-BBM by 
providing additional resources necessary for expanding its physical coverage and improving its 
management  and  monitoring  mechanisms.  The  Project’s  approach  of  utilizing  the  design, 
modalities, and implementation structure of the ongoing program will help to align the Project 
with the Government’s own development program and strategies, enhance ownership, and 
improve the prospects of achieving common goals of improved service delivery, achievement of 
MDGs, and poverty reduction. By taking advantage of the investments that the Government has 
made in designing and implementing the PKPS-BBM, the Project will be able to achieve greater 
resource use efficiencies, and avoid duplications. 
 
2.  Building on Past Experiences and Lessons Learned 
27.  The  design  of  the  PKPS-BBM  builds  on  experiences  gained  from  successfully 
implementing a series of community-based development projects and programs. This design 
adopts a pro-poor geographic targeting of the villages, emphasizes extensive socialization of 
procedures  and  guidelines,  provides  elaborate  community  facilitation  in  planning  and 
implementation, utilizes simple and transparent funds flow mechanisms, incorporates checks 
and balances, and emphasizes operation and maintenance of completed works. In designing 
the  proposed  Project,  the  existing  PKPS-BBM  design  was  further  improved  upon  by 
incorporating  lessons  learned  from  the  PKPS-BBM’s  initial  implementation.  Design 
improvements include (i) simpler implementation arrangements, with IRIP approvals at the 
district level; (ii) recognition of a need for flexibility in grant size; (iii) provision of follow-on grants 
in villages that are large or devoid of basic infrastructure; (iv) a longer implementation period; (v) 
simple  and  objective  selection  criteria  for  districts,  villages,  and  infrastructure;  (vi)  due

9 
consideration to financial viability and cost effectiveness in selecting infrastructure works; and 
(vii) expanded monitoring and evaluation to include also process, impact, and outcome. 
 
3.  Poverty Targeting 
28.  The Project will be implemented in those eastern provinces of the country where the 
poverty levels are higher and progress toward MDGs is lower than the national average. Within 
these provinces, the Project will target remote and isolated villages in less developed districts 
that are infrastructure poor and have not received any recent infrastructure-related assistance. 
The systematic approach in selecting project villages and the nature of supported interventions 
should ensure that the majority of benefits will largely accrue to the poor. Nonetheless, a variety 
of measures will be used to ensure that poor and vulnerable groups are particularly targeted by 
the  Project,  including  (i)  representation  of  women  and  minority  groups  on  communities’ 
representative  committees,  and  (ii)  use  of  local  labor  and  materials  in  implementing 
infrastructure. The poverty reduction and social strategy is summarized in Appendix 5. 
 
4.  Public Disclosure and Countrywide Dissemination 
29.  The  PKPS-BBM’s  community-driven  development  approach  has  been  widely 
disseminated throughout the country and is currently being implemented in about 427 districts. 
The  detailed  guidelines  for  community  mobilization  and  technical  design  for  typical  rural 
infrastructure have been developed in Bahasa Indonesia (the country’s national language) and 
disseminated to the districts and subdistricts. As a part of the ongoing PKPS-BBM, the Project 
will  benefit  from  the  dissemination  activities  that  have  already  been  completed.  A  media 
campaign  will  be  undertaken  in  the  selected  villages,  subdistricts,  and  districts  to  ensure 
adequate  awareness  of  the  Project’s  approach  and  interventions.  At  the  village  level,  the 
communities  will  make  their  plans,  budgets,  and  financial  records  available  to  the  public. 
Summaries  of  the  plans,  progress  reports,  and  financial  records  will  also  be  posted  on 
signboards within the villages. A flow of information to the communities will be encouraged by 
requiring the districts and subdistricts to provide copies of the quarterly progress reports to the 
communities, which will help to cross-check the accuracy and completeness of reports. At the 
Project  level,  the  Government  and  ADB  will  disclose  the  Project-related  information  in 
accordance with ADB’s public communication policy.17 
 
5.  Community Ownership 
30.  The Project’s community-driven approach will help develop a sense of ownership among 
the community members. The experience from past community-driven development projects, 
both in and outside of Indonesia, shows that strong community ownership is often reflected in 
better work quality and voluntary contributions that are far and above the required contribution. 
A recent evaluation18 of rural infrastructure schemes implemented by  communities in KDP 
phases I and II shows that, on average, communities’ voluntary contribution was about 17%.  
 
31.  Another indicator of community ownership is the better upkeep and maintenance of the 
infrastructure. Experience suggests that while the maintenance of larger infrastructure is beyond 
the communities’ capabilities, communities can maintain smaller infrastructure, if the community 
has been fully involved in all stages of planning and implementation—and including preparation

6.  Good Governance and Anticorruption Measures 
32.  Implementation  of  infrastructure  works  through  a  community-led  approach  is  the 
underlying principle of the Project design. The Project clearly recognizes that administration at 
the village level is the most transparent and democratic in the country and that there are several 
self-governing checks and balances at the village level to militate against corruption. Given that 
the Project aims to alleviate poverty, the main thrust of the anticorruption agenda has been to 
ensure that the beneficiaries directly receive the funds with the minimum amount of delay and 
that there are no leakages at the village level. The communities will be involved at all stages of 
infrastructure  rehabilitation  and  improvement.  The  Project  incorporates  good  governance 
through features including (i) advance socialization of the overall program objectives so that the 
communities understand the intentions, the outcomes, and the process by which funds will be 
disbursed;  (ii)  a  detailed  and  consensual  approach  to  planning  so  that  the  village-level 
assessments are prepared in a transparent, consistent, and cost-effective manner with clear 
awareness in the communities as to how much they are receiving and for what; (iii) smooth, 
transparent,  fast,  and  direct  disbursement  and  funds  flow  to  the  village;  (iv)  transparent 
utilization of Project funds at the village level, so that the utilization is adequately controlled with 
regular and transparent record keeping; and (v) comprehensive monitoring and evaluation that 
allows for an independent assessment of the village investment outputs compared to the plan 
and overall program objectives. 
 
33.  Implementation  through  such  a  transparent  approach  is  well  tested  and  proven  for 
promoting good governance. Details from an assessment of existing financial management

7.  Women’s Participation 
36.  Men and women engage in different socioeconomic activities, and consequently their 
infrastructure needs are not necessarily the same. The Project’s inherent approach will ensure 
equal  benefits  for  both  men  and  women.  Specific  measures  for  ensuring  balanced 
representation and equal participation of genders in all stages of infrastructure rehabilitation and 
improvement  include  (i)  having  at  least  20%  representation  of  women  in  representative 
committees, and among village organizers; (ii) ensuring at least 33% women’s participation in all 
training activities; and (iii) screening of IRIPs to ensure proportional employment opportunities 
for women. 
 
8.  Social Safeguards 
37.  The civil works included in the Project will be limited to rehabilitation and improvements 
to  existing  infrastructure,  and  these  shall  not  involve  resettlement  of  people,  relocation  of 
houses, or land acquisition.  
 
38.  The Project will proactively include indigenous people among its beneficiaries. Because 
the  Project  will  not  involve  negative  impacts  and  will  be  fully  based  on  community-driven 
development principles, compliance with the ADB policy on indigenous peoples20 will be de 
facto ensured by the main design and implementation mechanisms. Nonetheless, the selection 
criteria  for  infrastructure  include  provisions  to  ensure  that  indigenous  people  and  other 
vulnerable  groups  are  part  of  the  capacity  building,  planning,  implementation,  and  post-
implementation processes, as well as that they will benefit proportionally from the improved 
access to rural infrastructure, the training, and construction-related employment opportunities. 
 
9.  Environmental Safeguards 
39.  All schemes selected under the Project at the village level will undergo rigorous technical 
and  social  evaluation  prior  to  actual  project  approval  and  implementation.  By  using 
environmental screening criteria specified in the environmental assessment framework given in 
Appendix 8, only those schemes having no or very minimal environmental impacts will be 
selected.

1.  Project Management and Coordination 
44.  The Project will follow the established implementation arrangements for the PKPS-BBM,

nongovernment  organizations,  a  university,  the  press,  prominent  leaders,  and  the  general

45.  A project coordination and monitoring unit (PCMU) has been established in the DGHS to 
work closely with the PKPS-BBM multi-agency provincial and district project coordination teams.

undertake such activities as preparing withdrawal applications that will be specific to the Project. 
Each participating village will establish a CIO. The CIO shall be either an existing village 
organization (formal or informal) or a new project organization, as decided by the local village

2.  Selection of Village Level Infrastructure 
47.  The selection of a village infrastructure project for financing will be subject to (i) the 
endorsement of a village plan by the entire representative committee, including those members 
representing women and minority groups; (ii) its providing proportional benefits and employment 
opportunities to women and minority groups; (iii) its having a village infrastructure focus and 
leading to improvement in the livelihoods of the poor or near poor; (iv) its having potential for 
immediate utilization by the poor or near poor; (v) its involving only the rehabilitation and 
improvement of existing village-level infrastructure; (vi) its demonstrating economic viability and 
financial sustainability; (vii) its not requiring land acquisition or resettlement; (viii) its entailing no 
negative  environmental,  social,  or  economic  impacts;  (ix)  the  construction  period’s  not 
exceeding  3  months;  (x)  evaluation  of  alternative  designs  and  establishing  the  cost 
effectiveness of the proposed design; (xi) its utilizing local labor and materials, and, to the extent 
possible, employing technology that is simple or otherwise appropriate to local conditions; (xii) a 
village walk-through demonstrating the nature, location, and impacts of the project on at least 
50%  of  the  village  community;  and  (xiii)  the  CIO’s  having  prepared  an  operating  and 
maintenance  plan,  and  concluded  a  written  agreement  with  the  district  public  services  to 
maintain the works.

IV.  PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, ASSUMPTIONS, AND RISKS 
A.  Benefits and Impacts 
 
60.  Investment in priority rural infrastructure will directly benefit about 2 million people or 
400,000  households  in  1,800  villages  in  the  Project  area.  It  will  build  capacities  of  local 
governments  in  about  40  districts  in  community-driven  development.  Anticipated  benefits 
include (i) economic and financial returns; (ii) improved quality of life, with reduced poverty and 
vulnerability; and (iii) increased community and local government capacities. 
 
1.  Economic and Financial Benefits 
61.  Given the Project’s community-driven development approach, the communities would 
prioritize their infrastructure needs during the implementation, and it is therefore not possible to 
estimate an economic internal rate of return (EIRR) for the Project at this stage. There is a 
wealth  of  knowledge  and  experience  in  Indonesia  on  projects  pursuing  community-driven 
development and undertaking community-level interventions, however, and these could provide 
indicative bases for anticipating economic and financial viability for the key types of project 
interventions.  
 
62.  Appendix 15 summarizes the findings of evaluations undertaken on two recent projects 
with similar approaches and grant sizes. The results indicate that irrigation schemes yielded the 
highest returns, with the EIRRs for completed schemes ranging from 66% to 85%. EIRRs for the 
completed water supply schemes ranged from 28% to 36%, and those for roads and bridges 
from 33% to 47%. Using a general income multiplier analysis, the results indicated that, on 
average, the investments generated additional indirect incomes 17% in excess of the amount of 
cash  directly  injected  into  the  village  economies.  The  results  also  point  to  greater  cost 
effectiveness, with the works undertaken by communities on average costing 56% less than 
similar works carried out directly by government agencies or through contractors. 
 
63.  The  experience  on  these  projects  shows  that  the  majority  of  the  civil  works  are 
undertaken using manual labor, which accounts for about 30–50% of the civil works costs. 
Using a conservative estimate of labor accounting for 30% of the village grant utilization and 
average wage rates for skilled and unskilled construction labor, it is anticipated that, on average, 
an IRIP will generate 100 person-months of short-term employment. The overall short-term 
impact of the Project in generating employment is anticipated to be about 180,000 person-
months or 15,000 person-years. 
 
64.  On account of the large sunk costs that the Government has incurred in designing and 
implementing the PKPS-BBM, this Project’s economic and financial benefits are anticipated to 
be larger than if it was a stand-alone intervention.

18 
  
2.  Social and Poverty Reduction Benefits 
65.  The Project will target poor and isolated villages in less developed districts that lack 
basic infrastructure and have not received any recent support for developing or maintaining 
infrastructure. By virtue of poverty targeting, it is anticipated that the selected villages will have 
above average poverty levels and will be below the national achievement levels with regard to 
MDGs relating to eradicating poverty and hunger and improving access to water and sanitation. 
The water supply- and sanitation-related interventions are anticipated to reduce time and costs 
spent  on  obtaining  good  quality  water  while  diminishing  the  incidence  and  severity  of 
water-borne diseases. Improvements in rural roads are anticipated to increase the availability 
and accessibility of education, health services, and natural capital to the rural poor and near 
poor. A healthier population with improved access to services and markets, and with more time 
freed to engage in economic activities, will have the opportunity to improve its incomes and 
welfare. 
 
66.  The inclusion of women in planning, implementing and operational processes will ensure 
that the Project addresses their priority infrastructure needs and that they will benefit from 
training activities and employment opportunities. As women in these communities are typically 
and mainly responsible for collecting water, the benefits for women will be larger in cases of 
those interventions aimed at improving access to safe drinking water. 
 
3.  Institutional Benefits 
67.  The adoption of a community-driven development approach will lead to communities’ 
active involvement in prioritizing, planning, procuring, implementing, operating, and maintaining 
infrastructure. This will empower these communities and will prepare them to promote their own 
development. Improved governance at the local levels will be a result of the transparency in 
implementation, whereby all decisions will be made by the communities in public meetings, 
community  accounts  will  be  displayed  in  summary  in  public  places,  and  those  community 
accounts will be accessible for public scrutiny. 
 
68.  While the Project would cover villages that have not received any recent support for 
infrastructure  and  have  little  or  no  prior  exposure  to  community-driven  development,  the 
participating districts would have been involved in implementing the PKPS-BBM and other 
projects pursuing similar approaches. In fact, the Project relies on the awareness campaigns 
and capacity building activities that have already been completed by the PKPS-BBM, and it will 
limit its capacity building to refresher activities and improvements with regard to monitoring, 
governance,  and  safeguards.  The  governance-  and  monitoring-related  improvements  are 
anticipated to spill over to the PKPS-BBM activities being implemented within and outside of the 
Project districts. This will lead to improved targeting and accountability both inside and outside 
the Project area. 
 
B.  Risks 
 
1.  Adequacy of Government’s Preparatory Activities 
69.  The Project preparation largely relied on the Government’s own preparatory activities. 
While generally thorough, these may have been lacking in some areas. The loan fact-finding 
and appraisal missions undertook to assess the ongoing PKPS-BBM to ascertain any such 
weaknesses, and, where needed, additional provisions were added to address these. To further

19 
mitigate  risk,  additional  provisions  to  address  any  weak  areas  will  be  identified  by  an 
independent assessment of the PKPS-BBM planned for December 2005 or by the assessment 
of financial management systems at the inception stage. 
 
2.  Implementation Capacities at the Local Government Levels 
70.  The Project will be implemented in less developed districts of the country where the 
implementation capacities may not be on a par with those in the country’s more developed 
districts. The risk will be minimal, however, as the local governments will benefit from having 
implemented  the  PKPS-BBM  in  2005.  Thereby,  they  will  have  strengthened  their  relevant 
capacities.  Nonetheless,  the  Project  provides  for  additional  capacity  building  activities  and 
consulting services to help minimize risks related to capacity limitations. 
 
3.  Benefits Limited to a Few Non Poor 
71.  Experiences on past rural development projects show tendencies wherein the benefits 
are hijacked by a select few, and the needs of the poor largely remain unaddressed. This risk is 
minimized  by  several  features  in  the  Project  design.  These  include  establishing  the  CIO, 
electing community representatives and village organizers, ensuring representation of women 
and minority groups among the community representatives, and requiring that the majority of 
the community endorse the plans. Furthermore, all the civil works will be contracted to the CIOs 
and will be largely undertaken through manual labor. That will help to ensure that the benefits of 
generating employment accrue to the community members to the greatest extent possible. 
 
4.  Governance Related Issues 
72.  Infrastructure projects involving procurement of large amounts of goods and services for 
civil  works  are  generally  prone  to  corruption.  By  adopting  an  approach  wherein  planning, 
oversight, and implementation of the civil works rest with the communities, the Project promotes 
transparency and good governance. In addition, an assessment of the ongoing PKPS-BBM 
undertaken by ADB staff suggests that the existing financial management systems and fiduciary 
controls are sound and have adequate checks and balances to minimize the corruption-related 
risks. The financial management systems and fiduciary controls of the ongoing PKPS-BBM will 
be thoroughly assessed during the inception phase, and findings will be used to additionally 
strengthen the Project systems in order further to mitigate the related risks. Governance-related 
risks will be further minimized by implementing the action plan that had been jointly developed 
by the MPW and ADB to improve efficiency of project implementation, enhance quality of 
outputs, and prevent fraud and corruption. 
 
5.  Sustainability of the Policies and Investments 
73.  The PKPS-BBM is funded by the resources reoriented from the fuel subsidies, which 
amount to about $3.0 billion–$5.0 billion for 2005. As a significant proportion of the subsidies 
reduction came into effect in the last quarter of 2005, the total of reoriented funds is anticipated 
to be larger in 2006 and the Government should have no resource constraint for sustaining the 
PKPS-BBM. However, there is a potential risk that a substantial increase in world oil prices will 
generate  social  and  political  pressures  on  the  Government  to  increase  subsidy-related 
expenditures. That would reduce financial headroom for continuing the PKPS-BBM. This risk is 
real but low. The Government has been committed to its policy, and it has so far been effective 
in countering the adverse impacts of substantial increases in domestic prices by initiating safety 
nets and development programs.

20 
 
74.  Lack of adequate levels of operation and maintenance (O&M) could drastically reduce 
the  useful  lives  and  benefits  from  the  infrastructure  investments.  Experiences  from  the 
Community and Local Government Support Sector Development Program and KDP phases I 
and II show that ownership, and O&M are greater when the communities are involved in all 
stages of implementation. The Project’s community-driven development approach is geared 
towards  involving  communities  in  the  planning,  design,  implementation,  and  post-
implementation  stages.  The  risk  is  further  minimized  through  limiting  the  activities  to 
rehabilitation and improvement of existing infrastructure using local labor and materials. Limiting 
the infrastructure to simple design and focusing on the existing infrastructure, in particular for 
irrigation  and  water  supply,  will  have  the  advantage  that  existing  mechanisms  could  be 
strengthened through technical and social facilitation. Furthermore, approval of infrastructure 
rehabilitation and improvement will be contingent on preparation of O&M plans. 
 
6.  Start-up Delays 
75.  Because the Project is envisaged to be fast-disbursing and implemented over a short 
period of time, its performance will be sensitive to timely start-up of implementation activities. 
Past experience in cases of rural development suggests significant start-up delays could be 
expected  with  respect  to  establishing  project  implementation  offices  and  project  steering 
committees, finalization of funds flow mechanisms, recruitment of consultants, and approval of 
budgets.  The  Project  will  be  implemented  using  the  existing  approaches  along  with 
implementation and funds flow mechanisms that are already in place for the PKPS-BBM. The 
use  of  established  mechanisms  and  trained  staff  while  providing  advanced  action  for 
procurement of consulting services will minimize the risks of delays in project start-up.  
 
7.  Delays in Budget Approval 
76.  Ongoing projects have been experiencing systematic delays in release of budget funds, 
which leads to a shorter implementation period during a given year. The Government is in the 
process of introducing a new budget approval process, which aims to make the funds available 
to the line agencies at the start of the year. Nonetheless, the Project design addresses the 
potential for delays by scheduling the consultant- and facilitator-led community mobilization 
activities at the start of the year and civil works in the latter part of the year. 
 
8.  Lack of Counterpart Funds 
77.  A recurring problem in the past has been the availability of sufficient counterpart funds. 
This has led to implementation delays and an inability for projects to keep up with planned 
implementation schedules. The Government’s strong ownership of PKPS-BBM and the Project’s 
use of existing implementation mechanisms will help ensure that the Project will maintain high 
priority within the Government’s planning and resource allocation processes. Furthermore, the 
Project’s  requirement  for  counterpart  funds  is  minimal  and  should  not  lead  to  excessive 
difficulties in maintaining these levels.

1.  Some 60% of Indonesia’s population lives in rural areas, and rural poverty remains 
greater than urban poverty. In 2004, 11.4 million or 12.4% of the urban population and, 24.7 
million or 20.0% of the rural population was assessed to be poor.1  More than half of the 
population still lives on incomes slightly above the poverty line.2 From the 1970s to the 1990s, 
there was little difference between poverty rates in the urban and rural areas, as the gap never 
exceeded 2.5 percentage points in either direction. Since, 1999, at which time the gap widened, 
rural poverty has been consistently 8 percentage points above the urban level. There is a strong 
linkage  between  poverty  and  lack  of  access  to  infrastructure.  Improved  local  community 
infrastructure can result in better health and education, safer water supply and sanitation, and 
better access to economic opportunities. All of these are basic rights stated in the Government's 
poverty reduction strategy paper (PRSP), as incorporated into the Medium Term Development 
Plan for 2005–2009. The provision of infrastructure for poor communities will also help achieve 
the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs), namely targets 1, 3 and 10.   
 
2.  Indonesia’s  present  investment  levels  in  infrastructure  as  a  proportion  of  GDP  are

there are significant infrastructure deficiencies. Road density levels are 1.6 km/1,000 people, 
with 56% of the total 240,946 kilometers of district roads classified as damaged. Only 16% of 
rural populations are serviced by piped or pumped water supplies. Electricity consumption is just 
319 kwh/capita, with 45% of households not connected to electricity at all. Some 90 million 
people (mostly poor) do not yet have access to electricity. Only 3% of urban areas are served with 
fixed-line telephones, and there are just 27 lines per 1,000 people.4 The estimated need for 
infrastructure investment in Indonesia for 2006–2010 is $72 billion ($14.4 billion per annum).5

6.  Improving  the  road  transport  network  is  important  for  the  country’s  economic

1.  Recent ADB Project Design 
14.  The  generation  of  projects  formulated  under  decentralization  has  concentrated  on 
improving service delivery mechanisms and standards. Many of these new generation projects 
were community-based projects and achieved significant success at the community level. The 
participatory evaluation carried out as part of the country assistance program evaluation for 
Indonesia in September 2005 suggests that projects with strong participatory components have 
been effective in supporting village-level decentralization. In these community projects, project 
processes have played an important part in promoting greater transparency and community 
authority in decision making, as well as to make communities feel empowered to challenge 
village  government  for  greater  political  and  financial  accountability.  Appendix  3  gives  an

2.  Community and Local Government Support Program (CLGS) 
15.  The pro-poor CLGS7 program successfully helped to build capacities among village 
communities to identify, plan, implement, and manage small-scale infrastructure projects. It also 
addressed governance-related issues of participation, transparency, and accountability. Local 
governments demonstrated their strong appreciation for the Project and its contributions to 
village development and the building of capacities in handling bottom-up development with a 
large  number  of  community  groups.  The  communities  and  particularly  the  local  women’s 
organizations were a driving force for subproject identification, planning, and implementation. 
   
16.  In 79 districts, CLGS supported labor intensive construction of 17,237 public facilities. It 
generated 11 million workdays8 for 378,000 participants. The work was in the areas of (i) water 
supply, (ii) drainage, (iii) irrigation, (iv) local roads and bridges (60%), (v) public toilets, (vi) 
markets, (vii) school buildings, (viii) sanitation (solid waste handling or disposal), and (ix) water 
transport facilities such as piers and docks. Loan utilization was effective and efficient. The 
CLGS program’s community-based development efforts are known for their high degree of 
transparency. Communities have added substantially through additional noncash contributions, 
amounting  occasionally  to  2–3  times  the  value  of  the  project  funding.  The  contribution  of 
communities  has  diminished  the  need  for  contractors,  and,  through  the  mechanism  of 
community  supervision,  reduced  costs  for  subprojects.  Communities  have  been  willing  to 
commit to operating and maintaining facilities built under the Project.  
 
3.  Kecamatan Development Project (KDP)  
17.  The  Kecamatan  (subdistrict)  Development  Project  is  the  longest-running  externally 
funded community rural infrastructure and livelihoods project in Indonesia. Its goals are to 
alleviate  poverty  by  raising  rural  incomes,  to  strengthen  local  government  and  community 
institutions, and to promote good governance. Through its three phases and with funding of 
nearly $700 million, the KDP has so far provided some 56,000 units of infrastructure to about 
28,000 villages.9 
 
18.  By pushing decision making down to the lowest levels, the KDP empowers the rural poor 
and encourages more democratic and participatory forms of local governance. All KDP activities 
aim at allowing villagers to make their own choices about the kinds of projects that they need 
and want. The program gives power to communities by placing funds and the planning and 
decision-making processes directly under their control. The Project devotes extensive resources 
for social and technical facilitation at the village level, which can typically be 4 to 6 months long. 
In open public meetings, villagers decide upon a maximum of two proposals for forwarding to 
the final round of subdistrict-level decision making. Later, during the subdistrict-level meetings, 
elected representatives of all villages select proposals for allocation of funds. In cases of the 
selected proposals, the block grants are provided directly to the villages for undertaking small-
scale infrastructure, and social and economic activities. While the KDP does not fix the size of

D.  Lessons Learned 
1.  Key Experience from Rural Development Projects 
21.  Community-driven  rural  development  programs  operating  on  principles  of  local 
empowerment,  participatory  governance,  demand-responsiveness,  greater  downward 
accountability, and enhanced local capacity have been successfully implemented in Indonesia. 
Experience has shown that, given clear and appropriate implementation arrangements, access 
to information, and adequate capacity and financial support, poor men and women, working in 
partnership with local governments and other supportive institutions, can effectively organize in 
order to identify community priorities and implement works addressing local problems. 
22.  Pro-poor  targeting  of  villages  increases  the  poverty  impact  of  rural  development. 
Implementation arrangements need to ensure that within a participating community the vulnerable 
groups benefit directly during implementation. 
 
2.  Demand-Driven, Community-Based Development 
23.  Key lessons learned from demand-driven, community-based development in Indonesia 
and other Asian countries center on the importance of (i) manageable geographic coverage of a 
project; (ii) a simple technology menu for communities to chose from; (iii) engagement of 
communities  in  the  whole  project  cycle;  (iv)  extensive  use  of  community  facilitators;  (v) 
community contributions for construction, and full responsibility for operation and maintenance 
costs; (vi) close monitoring of construction quality and transparent project administration and 
procurement  procedures;  and  (vii)  community  participation  in  monitoring  and  evaluation 
activities.       
 
3.  Project Design and Implementation 
24.  Key lessons in project design are describe below: 
(i)  It is helpful to simplify implementation and to minimize government agencies’ 
involvement at various administrative levels. 
(ii)  Recent decentralization poses a challenge, in that more hierarchical levels want 
a  say  in  project  implementation.  Advantageous  is  to  have  a  single  project

Appendix 1  27 
management organization with sufficient authority to resolve coordination and 
implementation  issues  in  a  timely  manner.  Where  feasible,  decision  making 
should be delegated to lower levels. 
(iii)  Fund channeling arrangements must be simple and directly to the accounts of 
the village organizations, bypassing other institutions where it could be leaked. 
(iv)  Community facilitators represent a key factor in ensuring a project’s success, as 
they  are  responsible  for  community  planning  and  preparation  before  the 
construction  of  facilities.  Facilitator  recruitment,  training,  supervision,  and 
replacement needs to be delivered in a timely and synchronized manner. 
(v)  Communities should be encouraged to increase their voluntary contributions.  
(vi)  Work  quality  needs  to  be  monitored.  Low  quality  of  construction  has  been 
attributed to requirements to use unskilled and untrained village labor, combined 
with lack of supervision. 
(vii)  Monitoring  of  participating  consultants,  nongovernment  organizations, 
government agencies, and private sector organizations is crucial. Communities 
should be adequately trained to demand and recognize high quality construction 
and  assistance.  In  addition,  professional  and  regular  independent  quality 
monitoring and control of activities is needed. 
(viii)  Ensuring full transparency and public accountability of project administration and 
procurement is crucial to stimulating community participation and commitment to 
project policies and procedures. 
(ix)  Sectoral  projects  are  notoriously  slow  and  cumbersome  in  implementation, 
leading  to  great  frustration  among  initially  very  motivated  communities.  To 
address this, advance actions well in advance of project implementation are 
needed in establishing and staffing central- and district-level project offices and 
recruiting central-level consultants. 
(x)  Administration  and  procurement  procedures  should  be  clearly  explained  to 
communities so that they are capable of monitoring progress from their side, as 
well. Such accountability procedures as public disclosure of budgets, tenders, 
contracts, and terms of reference will ensure good governance and help prevent 
fraud and corruption.

E.  Background 
1.  The  Medium  Term  Development  Plan  (MTDP)  outlines  the  need  for  increasing 
investments in rural infrastructure development to reduce poverty in the rural areas. In a broader 
context, MTDP envisages reorienting public expenditures from consumption subsidies to more 
targeted support for the poor and near poor. At the end of 2004, the Government announced 
plans to increase fuel prices and use savings in fuel subsidies for poverty reduction programs 
covering  the  areas  of  health,  education,  nutrition,  and  rural  infrastructure  development. 
Preparatory  activities  then  began  for  various  initiatives,  including  the  rural  infrastructure 
component of the Fuel Subsidy Reduction Compensation Program (PKPS-BBM).  
 
F.  Program Formulation 
2.  The Program formulation spanned a period of 6 months (January–June 2005). Guided 
by  the  National  Planning  and  Development  Agency  (BAPPENAS),  the  initial  preparation 
involved  developing  the  Program’s  underlying  principles  and  basic  framework,  as  well  as 
assessing demand for rural infrastructure and implementation capacities. In the later stages, the 
focus was mainly on defining the detailed program scope and implementation arrangements. 
 
3.  Development of Program Framework. The regional development directorate of the 
BAPPENAS,  tasked  with  coordinating  and  implementing  roles  on  several  ongoing  and 
completed rural development projects, was a key player in developing the basic framework for 
supporting rural infrastructure development. The preparation, largely utilizing the Government’s 
own capacities, involved an extensive process of consultations with the implementing agencies 
involved in such successful community-driven development projects as ADB’s Community and 
Local Government Support (CLGS) program, World Bank’s Kecamatan Development Project 
(KDP), and Japan Bank for International Cooperation’s Rural Area Infrastructure Development 
Project. The initiative draws upon the strengths of these successful programs for alleviating 
poverty  by  raising  rural  incomes,  strengthening  local  institutions,  and  promoting  good 
governance.  The  framework  for  the  support,  based  on  a  community-driven  development 
approach, was completed in February 2005. The framework’s approval and announcement of 
the 1 March 2005 fuel price increase marked the start of the more detailed stage of preparation. 
 
4.  Assessment of Potential Demand. The BAPPENAS-led team undertook an extensive 
effort to identify infrastructure-deficient villages. Using 2003 data from the village potentials 
survey,1 the core design team used per capita availability of infrastructure and other indicators 
to identify villages that were deficient in the basic infrastructure. In total, about 28,000 villages 
were identified as infrastructure deficient. The results also indicated a strong correlation of poor 
and remote villages with lack of basic infrastructure. The village potentials survey, however, only 
reports on the presence of infrastructure and does not report on the adequacy or condition of 
existing infrastructure, which suggests that actual demand for rural infrastructure-related support 
may be larger than reported by the analysis. 
 
5.  Assessment of Implementation Capacities. As part of the Program formulation, the 
core design team also undertook to assess the implementation capacities compared to those

G.  Program Coverage and Village Selection 
7.  Given funding constraints and limitations in implementation capacities, about 12,800 of 
the 28,000 infrastructure-poor villages could be included in the 2005 phase. Distribution of the 
resources between the districts was governed by objective criteria based on a given district’s 
development status. The districts across the country were categorized into (i) less developed or 
disadvantaged, (ii) better off, and (iii) kota (cities). Within each of these categories, the districts

and fiscal situation. The less developed or disadvantaged category was accorded the highest 
priority, and, depending on the subcategorization, within each of the districts, 40 to 55 villages

H.  Program Approach and Scope 
9.  Similar  to  the  KDP  phases  I,  II  and  III,  the  CLGS  program,  and  the  Rural  Area 
Infrastructure  Development  Project,  the  Program  adopts  a  community-driven  development 
approach.  Similar  to  the  village  infrastructure  development  activities  in  these  projects,  the 
Program empowers communities to prioritize their infrastructure needs, plan and design the 
infrastructure, undertake the implementation, and operate and maintain the infrastructure. 
 
10.  The  PKPS-BBM  comprises  two  subcomponents:  (i)  infrastructure  works  and  (ii) 
safeguarding or management and coordination. Their 2005 budget allocations were $320 million 
and  $10  million,  respectively.  Like  the  KDP  and  other  similar  projects,  the  infrastructure 
development subcomponent includes providing block grants to the communities for addressing 
priority infrastructure needs from an open menu of access, social, and productive infrastructures. 
Experience from the KDP and other past projects suggests that the typical priorities of the 
village population include village roads, village irrigation schemes, water supply and sanitation, 
markets, rural electrification, and small fish landing facilities. As in the KDP, each village is

entitled to a block grant of about $25,000, which could be used for one or more of the village’s 
infrastructure-related priorities. The eligible expenditures under the block grant would include 
materials, labor, and equipment rental. 
 
11.  Similar to the KDP and other similar projects, the infrastructure works are supported by 
close social and technical facilitation. The implementation follows a three-step approach: (i) a 
socialization, mobilization, and capacity building stage; (ii) an infrastructure implementation 
stage;  and  (iii)  an  operation  and  maintenance  stage.  In  the  first  stage,  the  community 
implementation organizations (CIOs) are facilitated in prioritizing the infrastructure needs, and in 
planning and designing the infrastructure. The CIOs elect a representative body to represent 
their interests and act in their behalf. CIO members are trained in record keeping, construction 
and supervision, and operation and maintenance. 
 
12.  In the second stage, the communities, with technical facilitation from district-level public 
works services, undertake the development of priority infrastructure. All works are undertaken 
by the CIOs utilizing their own labor and local equipment and materials. The Program, like the 
KDP, follows the approach of payment based on plans rather than actual expenditures, and 
disburses 40% of the block grant upon approval of the proposal and signing of the contract 
between the CIO and the district government. Disbursements to the CIO are made directly to 
the CIO account by the treasury. Disbursement of the next tranche of 40% is contingent on 
verifying progress of at least 36% against the plans. Similarly, the last tranche is released at 
verification of at least 72% progress. 
 
13.  In  the  third  stage,  communities,  with  social  and  technical  facilitation,  develop  and 
establish the operating and maintenance mechanisms. In the process, the CIO either reconfirms 
the existing representative committee or establishes a committee that is tasked with operation 
and maintenance responsibilities. The committee and the CIO are trained in operating and 
maintaining the scheme, and user fee mechanisms are established, if needed. 
 
14.  The PKPS-BBM includes a provision for a year-end independent assessment of the 
design’s soundness and effectiveness, as well as of the quality of the project outputs and 
impacts.  This  is  to  be  coordinated  by  the  Coordinating  Ministry  of  People’s  Welfare  and 
undertaken  by  universities  in  the  provinces  concerned.  The  assessment  will  look  for

1.  Planning 
7.  The villages are pre-selected based on predetermined poverty criteria that utilize data 
from the Central Statistics Agency. This is intended to provide objectivity in how the villages are 
chosen, reduce delays in selecting the villages, and allow some direct targeting of poor villages. 
This moves away from the competitive selection of villages as was used under the earlier

step in the process. 
 
8.  Villagers’ investment decisions are taken at the village community level. Village plans 
will be very much driven by local community imperatives and will be quarantined from influence 
by district or provincial authorities. Even traditional village-level hierarchies are bypassed, as the 
village head is encouraged not to be part of the design or implementation teams, but rather to 
take a quality assurance and external monitoring role. The planning procedures force the village 
plans to delineate clearly all aspect of the village investment costs in a predetermined format. In 
particular,  where  local  villagers  themselves  will  be  employed  the  plan  must  indicate  the 
individuals, the rates to be paid, and the length of time the individuals will be employed. Every 
village-level plan must be countersigned by the village team, an independent member of the 
village, and the village organizer prior to submitting the plan for funds release. The villages 
decide where to spend the money from an existing menu of options provided by the project 
guidelines.  As  mentioned  above,  these  guidelines  have  already  been  socialized  and 
disseminated. The role of the district-level project manager is mainly to ensure that a plan has 
been produced and implemented according to the guidelines. 
 
9.  Simplified procurement practices focus on the community level. It is noted that a large 
portion of the funds are allocated for block grants to the villages. Communities are not only 
allowed to plan the programs, but they must also implement them. It is up to the community to 
conclude as to whether the activities can be carried out by the community itself or whether it 
needs to be contracted out to external consultants. In that way, the community will take into 
consideration issues such as lack of technology, manpower, or equipment. Villagers will be 
allowed to procure goods and services based on local economic factors and need not be 
influenced by Government pricing procedures or the urban market economy. To further ensure 
that it will impact on poverty alleviation, the Project will be focused mainly on reconstruction and 
rehabilitation  in  specific  areas  rather  than  on  new  infrastructure  construction.  This  will 
significantly reduce the need for external contractors. Employment generation is encouraged, as 
it is recognized that villagers themselves will undertake many of these activities using their own 
labor. The Project allows for a greater degree of additional technical support in the earlier 
stages for project design and supervision.

10.  Disbursement per Village. The project allows for a fixed amount per village that is 
standardized and widely publicized so that all stakeholders know how much the village will be 
getting. As mentioned above, funds are disbursed upon completion of an approved plan that is 
formulated by a village. Disbursements will be in tranches, with each tranche representing a 
fixed  percentage  of  the  total  allocated  per  village.  Tranche  release  conditions  have  been 
publicized  in  a  clear  regulation  from  the  Ministry  of  Finance  (Treasury  regulation  No. 
02/PB/2005). They are clearly delineated in the procedures, socialized, standardized, and not 
onerous. The releases to the village are as follow: 
 
(i)  First  tranche.  Representing  40%  of  the  fixed  amount.  Released  following 
submission of the village’s physical and funds utilization plan. 
(ii)  Second tranche. Representing 40% of the fixed amount. Released when the 
implementation progress, in terms of value, has reached a minimum of 36%

reviewed  by  the  district.  This  report  would  include  detailed  supporting
