ENVIRONMENTAL ASSESSMENT AND REVIEW FRAMEWORK 
 
A.  Introduction 
 
1.  The Project is unlikely to have adverse environmental impact and has been rated in 
category C. No environmental impact analysis or initial environmental examination is required, 
but evaluating environmental implications of the specific schemes under the Project will be 
required. The infrastructure schemes to be supported by the Project will be selected during 
implementation.  This  environmental  assessment  and  review  framework  will  be  used  for 
screening  the  schemes  so  that  those  selected  meet  category  C  requirements  and  the 
Government’s  similar  environmental  management  requirements.  If  screening  identifies  any 
schemes requiring any additional environmental procedural requirements under ADB or the 
Government’s laws and policies, then those schemes will not be selected under the Project. 
 
B.  Overview of the Likely Schemes to be Assessed 
 
2.  The  Project  will  support  the  rehabilitation  and  improvement  of  small-scale  village 
infrastructure  through  a  community-driven  development  approach,  using  a  block  grant  of 
$25,000 equivalent to each village. The infrastructure may include village roads, bridges and 
culverts, village irrigation schemes, water supply and sanitation schemes, and drainage works. 
The activities will be undertaken by communities, largely through manual labor and using locally 
available materials. The activities will be small and in general will lead to improvements in 
people’s welfare, sustainable use of resources, and improved hygiene. These will result in 
environmental improvements. Given the small size of the interventions and provision of close 
technical and social facilitation to communities, potential negative environmental impacts will be 
minimal  and  can  be  readily  mitigated.  Nonetheless,  schemes  will  be  screened  through  a 
framework with appropriate checklists to ensure that there are no negative impacts. 
 
C.  Country’s Environmental Assessment and Review Procedure 
 
4.  Indonesia  has  its  own  environmental  impact  management  system  for  development 
projects, Analisis Mangenai Dampak Lingkungan Hidup, which specifies procedural steps and 
required mitigation measures. According to that system’s criteria, the overall Project does not 
require environmental assessment, but each individual scheme would need to be screened. 
 
D.  Environmental Screening Process and Implementation Arrangements 
 
5.  Before they are approved for project financing, all schemes will be reviewed by the 
project  implementation  unit  at  district  level  for  their  feasibility,  technical  soundness,  and 
compliance with environmental guidelines. Based on the screening processes (Supplementary 
Appendix C), those schemes will be selected that are deemed to have minimal environmental 
impact and demonstrate “equivalence” between ADB’s and the Government’s environmental 
requirements.  The  Project  provides  for  24  person-months  of  environmental  safeguard 
specialists. The consultants will train the provincial, district, and subdistrict staff in screening for 
environmental impacts and will undertake spot-checks on a sample of schemes to verify the 
thoroughness and accuracy of the screening process. The Project staff and consultants will 
facilitate the village implementation organizations to evaluate the proposed schemes and their 
designs  using  the  checklists,  existing  government  guidelines,  and  the  screening  criteria 
indicated  above.  Based  on  this  evaluation,  any  schemes  that  would  not  meet  the

BENEFITS ANALYSIS 
 
A.  Overview 
1.  The Project will support rural infrastructure rehabilitation and improvement, providing about 
1,800 villages with financial resources and technical backstopping for small interventions, including 
village roads, bridges and culverts, village irrigation schemes, water supply and sanitation. As 
village  investments  will  follow  a  community-based  approach,  designs  and  costs  of  selected 
interventions will be determined during implementation. Quantifiable benefits will arise from village 
rural investments as increased rural incomes and welfare, but, because beneficiaries determine 
investments, the Project’s actual inputs and outputs cannot be predicted up front. The Project, 
therefore, does not lend itself to a traditional economic analysis. 
 
B.  Likely Benefits and Impacts of Rural Infrastructure 
2.  Rural Infrastructure Benefits. The more common benefits expected to accrue include (i) 
time  savings  in  collecting  water  and  cost  savings  in  obtaining  water;  (ii)  emergence  of  new 
businesses due to access to a water supply; (iii) time and cost savings due to faster transportation, 
including  more  efficient  transportation  of  goods  to  market;  (iv)  increase  in  the  value  of  land 
adjacent to a new road; (v) new employment in the transport sector; (vi) increase in the value of 
agricultural land serviced by new irrigation works; (vii) increase in incomes due to better harvests 
resulting from reliable water supply; (viii) savings from potential damage to buildings and crops due 
to reduced flooding and improved irrigation, and (ix) creation of new businesses (roads). 
 
3.  Employment  Generation.  The  Government  of  Indonesia’s  Fuel  Subsidy  Reduction 
Compensation Program (PKPS-BBM) currently under implementation estimates that 30% to 50% 
of the total civil works inputs will consist of labor. Using a conservative estimate of 30% of village 
grant  utilization,  the  Project  is  anticipated  to  generate  an  average  of  100  person/months  of 
employment per village, or about a total 180,000 person/months. With an average labor wage of $3 
per day, the short-term employment income generated by the Project is anticipated to be about 
$14 million. 
 
4.  Poverty Reduction Impact. Infrastructure investments can also have a significant impact 
on poverty reduction, although their abilities to reduce poverty varies. This is greater where poverty 
is most widespread and with better poverty targeting of projects.36 A number of case studies and 
evaluations have confirmed that infrastructure development reduces rural poverty through many 
channels, such as improved growth in agricultural production, greater rural nonfarm employment, 
and  migration.  Nevertheless,  there  may  be  time  lags  between  the  investment  in  improved 
infrastructure and the positive impacts.37 Evidence from studies has shown that rural transport 
improvements, in particular, and which are usually the types of intervention most demanded by the 
communities, do (i) contribute to decreasing the costs to the poor for personal travel and goods 
transport; (ii) increase the range of opportunities for wage employment (thereby raising the price of 
labor in rural areas); and (iii) increase empowerment of the poor and their participation in local 
organizations,  activities  outside  the  rural  community,  and  local  political  processes  and 
management structures.38

village. Based on the approved plans, block grants are transferred directly to the community 
organizations’  bank  accounts.  These  funds  cover  construction  costs  related  to  materials, 
equipment, and labor. Unlike the PKPS-BBM, the grant size in the KDP is not fixed. However, the 
findings from evaluating the KDP phases I and II indicate that average grant size of about $24,000 
per  village  is  similar  to  the  grant  size  under  the  PKPS-BBM.  In  addition  to  the  types  of 
infrastructure eligible under the PKPS-BBM, the KDP also allows for health- and education-related 
infrastructure. Grant utilization for these additional purposes, however, has been less than 2% of 
the total. The construction activities under both the PKPS-BBM and KDP follow a community-led 
approach where the use of local labor, materials, and equipment is encouraged. 
 
11.  The  findings  from  the  KDP  implementation  show  that  project  has  been  successful. 
Investments in rural infrastructure development have been economically and financially viable and 
sustainable. Given that the PKPS-BBM follows a similar community-led implementation approach, 
supports similar types and size of infrastructure, and invests similar amounts, the returns from the 
PKPS-BBM are anticipated to be similar in size and nature. 
 
12.  Economic Benefits. Commissioned in 2005 by the Government of Indonesia and World 
Bank, an independent post-construction analysis of 113 rural infrastructure subprojects funded 
under the KDP confirmed significant economic benefits accruing to villages that planned and built 
infrastructure  facilities  following  a  community-based  approach. 41  The  average  cost  net  of 
community contribution for these subprojects was about $12,000. Given that under the KDP each 
village typically received support for two infrastructure subprojects, the average support for each 
village amounted to $24,000, which is similar to the grant size under the proposed Project. In this 
case, too, the villages have the option for undertaking works on more than one unit of infrastructure.  
 
13.  The  study  calculated  the  economic  internal  rates  of  return  (EIRR)  for  four  types  of 
infrastructures: (i) roads, (ii) bridges, (iii) water supply, and (iv) irrigation. The four types were 
chosen because they have been shown over time to be the dominant types of infrastructures 
requested by the villages (representing more than two thirds of the total investments). The overall 
weighted-average EIRR for all 113 projects was 51.4%. Table A15.1 shows how average EIRRs

14.  Quality of Life. The field survey carried out by the study concluded that of the 113 projects 
reviewed, 95% (108) were valued by the villagers as having a “strongly felt” or “felt” impact on the 
quality of life of the supported villages. This shows a high level of direct and indirect benefits 
accruing from the investments. 
 
15.  Cost-Effectiveness.  The  cost-effectiveness  analysis  carried  out  by  the  same  study 
reported that village infrastructure built through a community-based approach cost on average 56% 
less than equivalent works built through Ministry of Public Works or local government contracts, 
demonstrating significant cost savings and additional economic value. The technical quality and 
project  management  of  94%  of  the  113  projects  reviewed  was  evaluated  by  the  villagers 
interviewed as very good or good. 
 
16.  Employment Generation. The total workdays generated from all the KDP infrastructure 
projects totaled 37 million for a total of 28,000 villages. Thus, on average, employment of 53 
person/months was created in each of the participating villages over the course of the project.  
 
17.  General Income Multiplier. A general income multiplier analysis was also undertaken. 
This  estimated  the  disposable  incomes  and  spending  patterns  of  key  groups  within  the 
communities to assess the impact of the funds spent by the projects as they circulated within the 
village economies. The study for the Government of Indonesia and World Bank shows that the 
cash injected by the 113 projects into the village economies generated significant additional value, 
with an average multiplier for the 113 projects of 1.165. The multipliers in the various project
